Events.RelatedBody:
> This issue is a locked mirror of https://github.com/dotnet/core/discussions/10157. See that thread for discussion.

We are pleased to announce the general availability of .NET 10.

Read about the final release on the [.NET Blog announcement](https://aka.ms/dotnet10).

This release contains improvements across the entire .NET stack. Check out the highlights below and the full release notes.

## ðŸ› ï¸ SDK

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/sdk.md)

## ðŸ“± .NET MAUI

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/dotnetmaui.md)

## ðŸŽ Entity Framework Core

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/efcoreanddata.md)

## ðŸ“š Libraries

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/libraries.md)

## â±ï¸ Runtime

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/runtime.md)

## C#

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/csharp.md)

## F#

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/fsharp.md)

## ðŸŒ ASP.NET Core & Blazor

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/aspnetcore.md)

## ðŸ–¥ï¸ Windows Forms

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/winforms.md)

## ðŸ–¥ï¸ Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF)

* [Full Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/10.0.0/wpf.md)

## ðŸš€ Get started

To get started with .NET 10, [install the .NET 10 SDK](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet/10.0).

If you're on Windows using Visual Studio, we recommend installing the latest [Visual Studio 2022](https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/download/). .NET 10 can be installed directly through the Visual Studio installer starting with Visual Studio 2022 17.13.

You can also use Visual Studio Code and the [C# Dev Kit](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-dotnettools.csdevkit) extension with .NET 10.

Celebrate the release of .NET 10 at [.NET Conf 2025](https://dotnetconf.net/) - November 11th - 13th.

## ðŸ”” Stay up-to-date with .NET 10

You can stay up-to-date with all the features of .NET 10 with:

* [What's new in .NET 10](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/whats-new/dotnet-10/overview)
* [What's new in C# 14](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/csharp/whats-new/csharp-14)
* [What's new in F# 10](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/fsharp/whats-new/fsharp-10)
* [What's new in .NET MAUI](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/maui/whats-new/dotnet-10)
* [What's new in ASP.NET Core](https://learn.microsoft.com/aspnet/core/release-notes/aspnetcore-10.0)
* [What's new in .NET Aspire](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/aspire/whats-new/)
* [What's new in Entity Framework Core](https://learn.microsoft.com/ef/core/what-is-new/ef-core-10.0/whatsnew)
* [What's new in Windows Forms](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/desktop/winforms/whats-new/net100)
* [What's new in WPF](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/desktop/wpf/whats-new/net100)
* [Breaking Changes in .NET 10](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/compatibility/10.0)
* [.NET 10 Releases](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/main/release-notes/10.0/README.md)

Additionally, be sure to subscribe to the GitHub Discussions [RSS news feed](https://github.com/dotnet/core/discussions/categories/news.atom) for all release announcements.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Upcoming Change to Nightly Build CDN - ci.dot.net" (#375) at dotnet/announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
On Tuesday, November 18, we will update the configuration of our nightly build CDN at https://ci.dot.net/
As part of our ongoing SFI work, we will disable anonymous access to the underlying blob storage.

This change means that any scripts or automation accessing nightly builds directly via Storage Account blob URLs will no longer work.

If your automation relies on direct access to blob URLs https://dotnetbuilds.blob.core.windows.net/, please update it to use the CDN endpoint instead: https://ci.dot.net/

### Describe the bug

When building a .NET 9 project with .NET SDK 9.0.304 and 10.0.100-rc1 installed, the build fails with the following error:

> `Error: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\10.0.100-rc.1.25451.107\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\targets\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.FrameworkReferenceResolution.targets(442,5): error NETSDK1127: The targeting pack Microsoft.NETCore.App is not installed. Please restore and try again. [D:\a\xunit\xunit\src\xunit.v3.assert.compat\xunit.v3.assert.all-on\xunit.v3.assert.all-on.csproj::TargetFramework=net9.0]`

### To Reproduce

This is being done on GitHub Actions, whose agents currently have 9.0.304 installed.

https://github.com/xunit/xunit/actions/runs/17740351193


To fix this, I forced an installation of 9.0.305 onto the agent:

https://github.com/xunit/xunit/actions/runs/17740712152

Note that I experienced the same issue on my personal dev box (which had 9.0.302 installed, as I had not yet updated VS2022). I'd written this off as being a local configuration issue related to uninstalling .NET 10 SDK Preview 7. Once it reproduced in Actions, I changed my belief to be that there is a compatibility issue, as the Actions agent has never had .NET 10 installed before I installed it during setup.

<details><summary>dotnet --info</summary>

For the broken build:

```

 Version:           10.0.100-rc.1.25451.107
 Commit:            2db1f5ee2b

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.26100
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\10.0.100-rc.1.25451.107\

.NET workloads installed:
 [maui-windows]
   Installation Source: VS 17.14.36414.22
   Manifest Version:    10.0.0-preview.6.25359.8/10.0.100-preview.6
   Manifest Path:       C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk-manifests\10.0.100-preview.6\microsoft.net.sdk.maui\10.0.0-preview.6.25359.8\WorkloadManifest.json
   Install Type:        FileBased

 [maccatalyst]
   Installation Source: VS 17.14.36414.22
   Manifest Version:    18.5.10415-net10-p6/10.0.100-preview.6
   Manifest Path:       C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk-manifests\10.0.100-preview.6\microsoft.net.sdk.maccatalyst\18.5.10415-net10-p6\WorkloadManifest.json
   Install Type:        FileBased

 [ios]
   Installation Source: VS 17.14.36414.22
   Manifest Version:    18.5.10415-net10-p6/10.0.100-preview.6
   Manifest Path:       C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk-manifests\10.0.100-preview.6\microsoft.net.sdk.ios\18.5.10415-net10-p6\WorkloadManifest.json
   Install Type:        FileBased

 [android]
   Installation Source: VS 17.14.36414.22
   Manifest Version:    36.0.0-preview.6.169/10.0.100-preview.6
   Manifest Path:       C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk-manifests\10.0.100-preview.6\microsoft.net.sdk.android\36.0.0-preview.6.169\WorkloadManifest.json

Issues.Title: [release/3.1] Reset current_no_gc_region_info after leaving no gc region implicitly
Issues.Body:
Backport https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/73602.

## Customer Impact
Customers reported occasional `System.InvalidOperationException` with message `The NoGCRegion mode was already in progress` when calling `GC.TryStartNoGCRegion`. This is preventing them from using this optimization and impacting their cold start latencies.

## Testing
Customers have tried the fix on .NET 6 overnight and reported the exception never appears again. Meanwhile, there is an unpatched machine and observed 72 exceptions of the same type in the same time interval, proving this does fix the bug.

## Risk
Low. This only impact customer using `TryStartNoGCRegion`, and this is the right thing to do.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[release/3.1] Reset current_no_gc_region_info after leaving no gc region implicitly" (#28265)

Issues.Title: Migrate FabricBot Tasks to Config-as-Code
Issues.Body:
**TL;DR;** Requesting to add [FabricBot](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/fabricbot_overview) configuration associated with your repository to `.github/fabricbot.json`.

**Context**

FabricBot is now a [config-as-code-only](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/bot-config-as-code) platform. As a result, while you can still use the [FabricBot Configuration Portal](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/bot/?repo=dotnet/coreclr) to modify your FabricBot configuration, you can no longer save the changes. The only way to save changes to your configuration at the moment is to _export configuration_ from the portal and upload the exported configuration to `.github/fabricbot.json` in your repository. In this pull request, we are adding your FabricBot configuration to your repository at `.github/fabricbot.json` so that you can make changes to it going forward.

While the [FabricBot Configuration Portal](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/bot/?repo=dotnet/coreclr) is the *only way* to modify your FabricBot configuration at the moment, we have a feature on our backlog to publish the JSON schema defining the structure of the FabricBot configuration file. With the JSON schema, you can (1) use a plaintext editor of your choice to modify the FabricBot configuration file and use the schema to validate the file after editing or (2) [configure](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/languages/json#_json-schemas-and-settings) VS Code to use the schema when editing FabricBot configuration file to take advantage of convenience features such as automatic code completion and field description on mouseover.

[*Pull Request Create*](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/prcreate), a [MerlinBot](https://https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot) Extension, was used to automatically create this pull request. If you have any questions or concerns with this pull request, please contact [MerlinBot Expert DRI](mailto:merlinbotdri@microsoft.com).

Issues.Title: Migrate FabricBot Tasks to Config-as-Code
Issues.Body:
**TL;DR;** Requesting to add [FabricBot](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/fabricbot_overview) configuration associated with your repository to `.github/fabricbot.json`.

**Context**

FabricBot is now a [config-as-code-only](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/bot-config-as-code) platform. As a result, while you can still use the [FabricBot Configuration Portal](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/bot/?repo=dotnet/cli) to modify your FabricBot configuration, you can no longer save the changes. The only way to save changes to your configuration at the moment is to _export configuration_ from the portal and upload the exported configuration to `.github/fabricbot.json` in your repository. In this pull request, we are adding your FabricBot configuration to your repository at `.github/fabricbot.json` so that you can make changes to it going forward.

While the [FabricBot Configuration Portal](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/bot/?repo=dotnet/cli) is the *only way* to modify your FabricBot configuration at the moment, we have a feature on our backlog to publish the JSON schema defining the structure of the FabricBot configuration file. With the JSON schema, you can (1) use a plaintext editor of your choice to modify the FabricBot configuration file and use the schema to validate the file after editing or (2) [configure](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/languages/json#_json-schemas-and-settings) VS Code to use the schema when editing FabricBot configuration file to take advantage of convenience features such as automatic code completion and field description on mouseover.

[*Pull Request Create*](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/prcreate), a [MerlinBot](https://https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot) Extension, was used to automatically create this pull request. If you have any questions or concerns with this pull request, please contact [MerlinBot Expert DRI](mailto:merlinbotdri@microsoft.com).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Migrate FabricBot Tasks to Config-as-Code" (#13832)

Issues.Title: Referencing netstandard 2.0 from WebSITE targeting .Net 4.8
Issues.Body:
I am having an issue referencing packages that target .NetStandard 2.0 from my webSITE (not application) project which targets .Net 4.8.

I see the following error:


> warning MSB3268: The primary reference "D:\a\1\s\iSAMS.Web.Controls\bin\Release\net48\iSAMS.Web.Controls.dll" could not be resolved because it has an indirect dependency on the framework assembly "netstandard, Version=2.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=cc7b13ffcd2ddd51" which could not be resolved in the currently targeted framework. ".NETFramework,Version=v4.8". To resolve this problem, either remove the reference "D:\a\1\s\iSAMS.Web.Controls\bin\Release\net48\iSAMS.Web.Controls.dll" or retarget your application to a framework version which contains "netstandard, Version=2.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=cc7b13ffcd2ddd51".


I have already added an assembly reference to the web.config as follows but it doesn't work:

```
<assemblies>
          <add assembly="netstandard, Version=2.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=cc7b13ffcd2ddd51" />
....
```

What am I doing wrong?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Referencing netstandard 2.0 from WebSITE targeting .Net 4.8" (#1771)

Issues.Title: Value Tuple Could not load file or assembly 'System.ValueTuple, Version=4.0.1.0,
Issues.Body:
[tuple-not-loading-log.txt](https://github.com/dotnet/standard/files/5606091/tuple-not-loading-log.txt)

I have  web project which is targeted to 4.6.2 .net framework. This project is calling a framework library which is targeted to the same .net framework 4.6.2. But in the framework library project it is referencing the system.valuetuple of 4.3.0 via the nuget package. 
  <package id="System.ValueTuple" version="4.3.0" targetFramework="net461" />

This valuetuple 4.3.0 targets .net standard 1.0 and .net framework 4.5. But our UI project is targeting 4.6.2. And we are getting this valuetuple not able to load. Could you please tell me why so ? 

So if i am referencing a library that targets .net standard and .net framework of which the referencing project doesnt target to . How does the dll assemblies work here ? Really confused. Please help us

Basically I am getting this error. The detailed log is attached in tuple-not-loading file. 
_message: "ReflectionTypeLoadException: Could not load file or assembly 'System.ValueTuple, Version=4.0.1.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=cc7b13ffcd2ddd51' or one of its dependencies. The system cannot find the file specified."

 VS 2017 IDE is used to build the project

Issues.Title: Assembly version for DispatchProxy shim is too low resulting in duplicate types for DispatchProxy
Issues.Body:
Create a new `netstandard2.1` library.
Add a reference to `<PackageReference Include="System.Reflection.DispatchProxy" Version="4.7.1" />`
Try to use `DispatchProxy`

Expected: 
`DispatchProxy` is resolved from `netstandard.dll`

Actual:
```
error CS0433: The type 'DispatchProxy' exists in both 'System.Reflection.DispatchProxy, Version=4.0.6.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a' and 'netstandard, Version=2.1.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=cc7b13ffcd2ddd51'
```


Build contains conflict message:
```
Encountered conflict between 'CopyLocal:C:\src\dotnet\runtime\artifacts\bin\testPackages\cache\system.reflection.dispatchproxy\4.7.1\lib\netstandard2.0\System.Reflection.DispatchProxy.dll' and 'Runtime:C:\Program Files\dotnet\packs\NETStandard.Library.Ref\2.1.0\ref\netstandard2.1\System.Reflection.DispatchProxy.dll'. Choosing 'CopyLocal:C:\src\dotnet\runtime\artifacts\bin\testPackages\cache\system.reflection.dispatchproxy\4.7.1\lib\netstandard2.0\System.Reflection.DispatchProxy.dll' because AssemblyVersion '4.0.6.0' is greater than '4.0.5.0'.
```

Other shims avoid this by setting the AssemblyVersion higher than that which was previously shipped.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Assembly version for DispatchProxy shim is too low resulting in duplicate types for DispatchProxy" (#1791)

Issues.Title: Update docs to reflect the status of .NET Standard in 2020
Issues.Body:
My understanding is, .NET Standard isn't the plan for standard .NET anymore. [The plan is now .NET 5.](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/dotnet/the-future-of-net-standard/)

That isn't at all clear from the docs here which seem to be frozen in time. Suggest you make some slight edits to [faq.md](https://github.com/dotnet/standard/blob/master/docs/faq.md) and [README.md](https://github.com/dotnet/standard/blob/master/README.md) to reflect the new status of .NET Standard.

Issues.Title: Confusing behavior when using AssemblyInfo.cs
Issues.Body:
I'm completely perplexed.

I created a .Net Standard 2.0 library project.

I explicity added an AssemblyInfo.cs file, we need this because we use this utility to "stamp" our assemblies when we build them:

https://github.com/ygoe/NetRevisionTool

That utility is run as a pre/post build event and temporarily replaces placeholders in the AssemblyInformationalVersion attribute with runtime values (like repo folder name, commit ID, branch etc etc).

The completed assembly then has this info "burned" into it as we go forward.

.Net Standard is not working with this.

1. It seems to populatethe Package Version (in the project's Package section) with whatever we put into AssemblyInfo.cs for AssemblyInformationalVersion.
2. The version of the generated nuget package is always set as 1.0.0.

This is just mind blowing, is there no way we can do this seemingly simple operation any more if adopt .Net Standard?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Confusing behavior when using AssemblyInfo.cs " (#1775)

Issues.Title: Questions about tagging within this repository / future versions
Issues.Body:
I was looking through this repository to determine if .NET Standard 2.1 libraries support default interface methods - it looks like they do, given the presence of `System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RuntimeFeature.DefaultImplementationsOfInterfaces`, as well as my own experimenting in VS 2019. It seems I was mistaken when thinking that this was not the case, so I'm glad this repository is easily accessible to determine this.

But while doing this, I found it difficult to determine what commits were included in this particular .NET Standard version. I see that there's a tag `v2.1.0-prerelease.19126.1`, as well as branches `release/2.0.0`, `release/3.0`, and `release/3.0-preview9`. One of the machines I tested VS 2019 on had a `netstandard.dll` assembly, itself targeting .NETStandard v2.1.0, with AssemblyInformationalVersion `1.1.0+a5b5f2e1e369972c8ff1e2183979fab6099f52ef`; this commit is part of the `release/3.0` branch. However, another machine had a same-named assembly, targeting .NETCoreApp v3.0 and AssemblyInformationalVersion `3.0.0+4ac4c0367003fe3973a3648eb0715ddb0e3bbcea`, and I don't see that commit hash in this repository.

Additionally, [this blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/dotnet/the-future-of-net-standard/) states that 2.1 will be the last version, but there is another prerelease tag `v2.2.0-prerelease.19564.1` and [on GitHub](https://github.com/dotnet/standard/releases/tag/v2.2.0-prerelease.19564.1) it's labelled .NET 5.0 Preview 2.

So I have a few questions for understanding this repository:

1. Since .NET Standard 2.1 is released, are there plans to continue development in this repository for e.g. the shared BCL going forward with .NET 5+?
2. Are there multiple kinds of `netstandard.dll` for a single .NET Standard version? E.g. are there separate versions for .NET Framework to reference and for .NET Core / .NET 5+ to reference?
3. Do the tags / branch names in this repository correspond to a .NET Standard version or something else?
4. It looks like there are patch releases; are there patch versions of a single .NET Standard version?
5. Are there other repositories which are being used to create `netstandard.dll`?
6. Is there a way to determine, from the repository, which commit is the one used for a given release?

Thank you for your consideration.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Questions about tagging within this repository / future versions" (#1777)

Issues.Title: Issue with resolving between .NET Standard 2.0 and .NET Standard 2.1
Issues.Body:
# Summary

.NET Standard version is not resolved correctly when a transitive dependency targets multiple .NET Standard versions.

# Environment

- Windows 10 (19042.746)
- .NET 5 SDK 5.0.201

# Minimal reproducible example
[bug.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/standard/files/6209239/bug.zip)

This is a three-project solution:
- `TestProject1` targeting `netcoreapp3.1`
- `ClassProject1` targeting `netstandard2.0`
- `ClassProject2` targeting *both* `netstandard2.0` and `netstandard2.1`

The project dependency chain is: `TestProject1 -> ClassProject1 -> ClassProject2`

A method (`ClassProject2Test1`) on `ClassProject2` is hidden behind a `#if NETSTANDARD2_0` preprocessor directive.

# The issue

The unit test failed with a `MissingMethodException`

```
[xUnit.net 00:00:00.38]     TestProject1.UnitTest1.Test1 [FAIL]
  Failed TestProject1.UnitTest1.Test1 [2 ms]
  Error Message:
   System.MissingMethodException : Method not found: 'Void ClassLibrary2.Class2.Class2Test1()'.
  Stack Trace:
     at ClassLibrary1.Class1.Class1Test1()
   at TestProject1.UnitTest1.Test1() in C:\Users\rex\source\netstandard-bug-repro\TestProject1\UnitTest1.cs:line 12
```

# Expected result

The compiler should have resolved the chain as:

`TestProject1 (.NET Core 3.1) -> ClassProject1 (.NET Standard 2.0) -> *ClassProject2 (.NET Standard 2.0)*` 

# Actual result

The compiler resolved the chain as:

`TestProject1 (.NET Core 3.1) -> ClassProject1 (.NET Standard 2.0) -> *ClassProject2 (.NET Standard 2.1)*` 

Which causes the exception because the offending method, `ClassProject2Test1`, was hidden by the `#if NETSTANDARD2_0` preprocessor directive.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Issue with resolving between .NET Standard 2.0 and .NET Standard 2.1" (#1787)

Issues.Title: [BUG] [UWP] GetManifestResourceInfo doesn't work on UWP
Issues.Body:
# Summary
I was trying to access Embedded resources on UWP. Something like this

```C#
manifestResourceInfo = typeof(App).Assembly.GetManifestResourceInfo("UwpEmbeddedResourceBug.appsettings.json");
```
However, this doesn't work on UWP, even though it works like a charm on iOS for instance. 
Further, when you try to use this in UWP debug mode, it will return non-null `manifestResourceInfo`, however internally the `FileName` property will be null. But if you try to use the same on Release build, instead you will get an exception

System.PlatformNotSupportedException: Operation is not supported on this platform.
   at System.Func`1.BeginInvoke(AsyncCallback, Object) + 0x1f

Issues.Title: Security Vulnerability due to System.Text.RegularExpressions
Issues.Body:
### Problem
There is a security vulnerability with the version of System.Text.RegularExpressions that is used by dotnet standard. The vulnerable version of System.Text.RegularExpressions is 4.3.0. Please see links below for the vulnerability documentation or discussion:

https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/vulnerability/CVE-2019-0820
https://github.com/dotnet/announcements/issues/111
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-0820
https://snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-DOTNET-SYSTEMTEXTREGULAREXPRESSIONS-174708
https://www.whitesourcesoftware.com/vulnerability-database/CVE-2019-0820

The dotnet commit that fixed the vulnerability is https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/commit/19d4b1163d8a03dd90ff5fd1785eea6305112545

### Issue:
We use whitesource and it has caught this issue with high severity. We don't consume System.Text.RegularExpressions directly but packages that use this. Therefore as a transitive dependency due to NetStandard library, which is being used by several other dotnet packages like Castle Windsor, MassTransit etc., Once an update is available the others could followup and update.

### Code:

[The latest version 2.0.3 of Net standard ](https://www.nuget.org/packages/NETStandard.Library/) still seem to be using System.Text.RegularExpressions version 4.3.0 as per https://github.com/dotnet/standard/blob/master/src/apicompat/netstandard/netstandard.depproj

### Fix
Please update[ library](https://www.nuget.org/packages/NETStandard.Library/) targeting .netStandard 1.6 to update System.Text.RegularExpression package to latest secured version 4.3.1 to fix the security issue or kindly suggest alternatives.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Security Vulnerability due to System.Text.RegularExpressions" (#1786)

Issues.Title: linq using GetValueOrDefault  in Where clause problem
Issues.Body:
Hello,

I am currently using .NET core 2.2.x and EF Core. 2.2.6. I have a function that returns a List<Animal> from the database with no issue. It returns 11 results. However, when I try to use `.Where(p => p.DeletedAt.GetValueOrDefault(DateTime.Now) => DateTime.Now).ToList()`, it still should return 11 results, however it returns 0. I also eliminated the possibility that there is something wrong with my where clause (logic) because it works perfectly on 4.6.1 EF Core 2.2.6. Furthermore, I confirmed that it is only where I am comparing a nullable type using that function and I am guessing that I missed a thread someone opened on this issue. I am aware .NET core 2.2 is not LTS. I also thought this goes here because it's not AFAIK, an EF core issue but rather an Ienumerable/Linq issue.

Update: As it turns out your notion of `DateTime.Now` getting evaluated twice is true. To rectify that, I will now be using `DateTime.Now.Date`. This is odd because this exact code works on 4.6.1. You're probably right. SMH. Thank you @GrabYourPitchforks! You may now close.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "linq using GetValueOrDefault  in Where clause problem" (#1792)

Issues.Title: Strong name signature not valid
Issues.Body:
Since I've ported a ClickOnce application from .NET Framework 4.6.1 to .NET Standard 2.0, the message _"Strong assembly name signature not valid for **Microsoft.SqlServer.Assessment.Types.dll**"_ appears when trying to install or update the application. So the next step was to verify the assembly strong name by using the [Strong Name Tool](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/framework/tools/sn-exe-strong-name-tool) to make sure, that everything is fine, but:

```sh
> sn.exe -v Microsoft.SqlServer.Assessment.Types.dll

Microsoft (R) .NET Framework Strong Name Utility Version 4.0.30319.0
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Microsoft.SqlServer.Assessment.Types.dll is a delay-signed or test-signed assembly
```

Additional information:

- The assembly versions `161.46041.41` and `161.46367.54` ended up in the same result
- This issue looks very similar to [this](https://www.damirscorner.com/blog/posts/20140502-StrongNameValidationFailedSecurityException.html)
- @markingmyname / @olprod: The root package, which is required for [Server Management Objects (SMOs)](https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/server-management-objects-smo/overview-smo?view=sql-server-ver15), is:
  - [Microsoft.SqlServer.SqlManagementObjects](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.SqlServer.SqlManagementObjects)
    - Microsoft.SqlServer.Assessment
      - Microsoft.SqlServer.Assessment.Authoring
        - **Microsoft.SqlServer.Assessment.Types.dll**
- This issue appears on windows server machines but the software runs on different machines and I would like to avoid temporary workarounds such as editing the registry and activate the strong name bypass feature because of the forced validation on windows server machines
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Strong name signature not valid" (#1789)

Issues.Title: System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings slow
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/SystemDrawingPrintingPrinterSettings-/890524)._ --- Hello I'm debugging a problem with the printer settings. Some calls are significant slower if the default printer is a network printer, even if I explicit set a local printer name. After studying referencesource I think I found the culprit. I call: var printerSettings = new System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings(); printerSettings.PrinterName = "LOCALPRINTER"; // the next call is slow if the OS default printer is a network printer var res = printerSettings.DefaultPageSettings.PrinterResolution Internally FastDeviceCapabilities is called. FastDeviceCapabilities calls GetOutputPort. But GetOutput port return the port of the default printer and not the port of the given printer! In addition, DeviceCapabilities is then called with a wrong combination of printer name and port, don't know if this could lead to additional problems. Resolution: GetOutputPort should return the port of the given printer and not accessing the default printer at all. Best Regards, Raphael --- ### Original Comments #### Raphael Affolter on 1/20/2020, 04:03 AM:

I forgot to mention: .Net Framework 4.6.1

#### Feedback Bot on 1/20/2020, 06:51 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Raphael Affolter on 2/7/2020, 08:39 AM:

Because we print a lot, we really suffer from this performance penalty.

Also reading PaperSizes and PaperSources from the printer settings is slow caused by the same problem.

Could you please inform me about a possible fix?

Best Regards,

Raphael

#### Raphael Affolter on 2/7/2020, 10:33 AM:

In my opinion the fix is easy: replace GetOutputPort by OutputPort in the call to

FastDeviceCapabilities.

Done.

#### Feedback Bot on 2/27/2020, 05:40 PM: I have detected that for the last 35 days, this issue didn't have much product team activity and a very small amount of new votes or comments. Based on this, its severity, and affected area, itâ€™s my experience that this issue is very unlikely to be fixed. #### Dada Huo [MSFT] on 10/20/2020, 01:57 AM:

Thank you for taking the time to log this issue! Did you still reproduce this issue in the latest stable version of Visual Studio installed from https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/downloads ?

If so, in order for us to investigate further, please provide more information by recording your repro steps via the Visual Studio Feedback Tool (Help -> Send Feedback -> Report A Problem). The feedback tool will ensure that we collect the needed information for you without worrying about what to provide (recording, dump file or ETL trace). Since this issue is now marked as Need More Info, that workflow is enabled in the Feedback Toolâ€“ full instructions
In our guidelines , you can get tips on how to provide clear and simple reproducible steps.

Get performance issues fixed quicker, please see https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/how-to-increase-chances-of-performance-issue-being-fixed?view=vs-2019.

We look forward to hearing from you!

#### Raphael Affolter on 10/20/2020, 02:28 AM:

Thanks for answering.

The issue is not about Visual Studio, the problem is in the .Net Framework (at least 4.6.1).

By studying the source code on referencesource.microsoft.com I spotted calls to the default printer, even if I print on another printer. If the default printer is a network printer, this slows down the printing process significantly.

Please have a look if you can fix this in the .Net Framework(s).

PrinterResolution, PaperSizes and PaperSources of System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings are affected.

I also mentioned a fix: replace GetOutputPort by OutputPort in the call to FastDeviceCapabilities...done.

I you need a repro project, I can provide one.

--- ### Original Solutions #### Raphael Affolter solved on 3/19/2020, 07:18 AM, 0 votes:

I would be helpful if at least somebody reacts on this issue. I even told you how to fix the problem...
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings slow" (#1778)

Issues.Title: Build issues when referencing project that targets multiple frameworks C# WPF
Issues.Body:
I'm working on converting a large WPF solution's projects to SDK style and ran into some issues.

The solution is large with multiple projects(old style) all targeting .net452 and some nugets(some made by me) installed, targeting both .net452 and .netstandard2.1 This all seems to work fine, somehow the nuget manages to install the correct version targeting .net452.

I have decided to slowly convert the projects inside the solution to SDK style targeting .net452 and .netstandard2.1 just like the nugets.

This is where the problem starts, one project was converted so far that is referenced by multiple other projects. Localy everything seems to build and run fine, however when Azure DevOps(VS version 2019) is used to build the solution there are 2 scenarios:

1. The famous error message is shown:

                "Error CS0012: The type 'Object' is defined in an assembly that is not referenced. You must add a reference to assembly 
                 'netstandard, Version=2.1.0.0"

2. It builds fine but on app launch it crashes with:

                 "Could not load file or assembly 'netstandard, Version=2.1.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=cc7b13ffcd2ddd51' 
                 or one of its dependencies. The system cannot find the file specified."

I'm suspecting that the problem is related to referencing the SDK project, it looks like that somehow it references the .netstandard2.1 instead of the .net452.

The reason this is my suspicion is that if targetframework is set to only .net452 on the referenced project everything works fine. Google has led me to two possible solutions to tell the project what framework to use from the reference:

```
<ProjectReference Include="..\..\..\..\foo\foo.csproj"
                  AdditionalProperties="TargetFramework=net452">
      <Project>{xxxxxx-xxxxxx-xxxxx-xxxxx-xxxxxxx}</Project>
      <Name>foo</Name>
</ProjectReference>
```
and

```
<ProjectReference Include="..\..\..\..\foo\foo.csproj">
      <SetTargetFramework>TargetFramework=net452</SetTargetFramework>
      <Project>{xxxxxx-xxxxxx-xxxxx-xxxxx-xxxxxxx}</Project>
      <<Name>foo</Name>
</ProjectReference>
```
This doesn't look like it's doing anything and the problem still persists. At the moment I ran out of ideas and I'm here asking for help. Please let me know what I'm doing wrong or what else I can try.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Build issues when referencing project that targets multiple frameworks C# WPF" (#1776)

Issues.Title: [UWP] HttpClientHandler - Digest Authentication Broken on Windows 10 PC
Issues.Body:
Just recently I found that my UWP app can no longer connect with Digest authentication on Windows 10 PCs. I'm seeing the same issue this individual posted the other day on the Microsoft Docs website.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/93105/httpclienthandler-does-not-work-for-authentication.html

The same code works fine on my Android, iOS, & Windows 10 Mobile devices. To take it a step further, the exact same UWP appxbundle that works on my Windows 10 Mobile Phone, does not work on my Windows 10 PC.

This is specific to only the UWP HttpClientHandler. On my Windows 10 PC, the HttpClientHandler in .NET Framework 4.8 still works fine.

Like I said, this is a new issue. The System.Net.Http.HttpClientHandler on UWP definitely did support Digest up until about a week ago.

My appxbundle was built with Target version 10.0.17134, Min version 10.0.15063.

I also tested with the latest & the problem still persists; Target version 10.0.18362, Min version 10.0.18362.

DOES NOT WORK
-------------------
UWP on Windows 10 Pro 2004 19041.508

WORKS
--------
UWP on Windows 10 Mobile 1709 10.0.15254.556
.NET Framework 4.8 on Windows 10 Pro 2004 19041.508
Android
iOS


Here's the return response I get:

{StatusCode: 401, ReasonPhrase: 'Unauthorized', Version: 1.1, Content: System.Net.Http.StreamContent, Headers:
{
  Server: lighttpd/1.4.35
  Date: Wed, 16 Sep 2020 03:38:24 GMT
  WWW-Authenticate: Digest realm="iPolis_00:16:6C:7A:A3:80", nonce="e2f7fe3344e6b521c2b83c56aa48fc17", qop="auth"
  Content-Length: 351
  Content-Type: text/html
}}
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[UWP] HttpClientHandler - Digest Authentication Broken on Windows 10 PC" (#1774)

Issues.Title: Migrate FabricBot Tasks to Config-as-Code
Issues.Body:
**TL;DR;** Requesting to add [FabricBot](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/fabricbot_overview) configuration associated with your repository to `.github/fabricbot.json`.

**Context**

FabricBot is now a [config-as-code-only](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/bot-config-as-code) platform. As a result, while you can still use the [FabricBot Configuration Portal](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/bot/?repo=dotnet/corefx) to modify your FabricBot configuration, you can no longer save the changes. The only way to save changes to your configuration at the moment is to _export configuration_ from the portal and upload the exported configuration to `.github/fabricbot.json` in your repository. In this pull request, we are adding your FabricBot configuration to your repository at `.github/fabricbot.json` so that you can make changes to it going forward.

While the [FabricBot Configuration Portal](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/bot/?repo=dotnet/corefx) is the *only way* to modify your FabricBot configuration at the moment, we have a feature on our backlog to publish the JSON schema defining the structure of the FabricBot configuration file. With the JSON schema, you can (1) use a plaintext editor of your choice to modify the FabricBot configuration file and use the schema to validate the file after editing or (2) [configure](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/languages/json#_json-schemas-and-settings) VS Code to use the schema when editing FabricBot configuration file to take advantage of convenience features such as automatic code completion and field description on mouseover.

[*Pull Request Create*](https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot/extensions/prcreate), a [MerlinBot](https://https://eng.ms/docs/products/1es-data-insights/merlinbot) Extension, was used to automatically create this pull request. If you have any questions or concerns with this pull request, please contact [MerlinBot Expert DRI](mailto:merlinbotdri@microsoft.com).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Migrate FabricBot Tasks to Config-as-Code" (#43150)

Issues.Title: Fix RSA OAEP decryption in OpenSSL with non-power-of-two keys lengths
Issues.Body:
## Customer Impact

A customer reported in dotnet/runtime#71607 that decrypting RSA OAEP with SHA2 and a 3072-bit key on Linux resulted in a OAEP de-padding error, while other platforms were able to perform these operations successfully.

Investigation in to the issue led to uncover that RSA OAEP decryption that uses the managed implementation does not work with non-power-of-two keys because we do not slice a rented buffer accordingly. The current implementation only works because `CryptoPool.Rent` happens to give back power-of-two arrays which are exactly the same size as the key.

The fix is to slice the data to the correct size.

This does not affect dotnet/runtime because the managed implementation of RSA OAEP is no longer used for OpenSSL RSA decryption. This change was introduced in dotnet/runtime#50063.

## Testing

Unit tests were introduced to test RSA OAEP encryption with a 3072-bit RSA key. These tests will be forward-ported to dotnet/runtime.

## Risk

Minimal. The change is localized and understood that a `Slice` was missing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix RSA OAEP decryption in OpenSSL with non-power-of-two keys lengths" (#43153)

Issues.Title: Improve error message for misplaced variable designator in property patterns
Issues.Body:
## Summary: Improve error messages when variable designation is in incorrect order with property pattern

### Problem Statement
When users write `o is string s { Length: 5 }` (with designation before property pattern), the compiler produced confusing error messages:
- `error CS1026: ) expected`
- `error CS1002: ; expected`
- `error CS1513: } expected`

The correct syntax should be `o is string { Length: 5 } s` (designation after property pattern).

### Solution
This PR adds a new error code `ERR_DesignatorBeneathPattern` (CS8525) that provides a clear error message:
```
error CS8525: The variable designator 's' must come after any property pattern.
```

### Changes Made

âœ… **Error Code & Resources:**
- Added `ERR_DesignatorBeneathPattern` error code (CS8525) to `ErrorCode.cs`
- Added error message to `CSharpResources.resx`
- Updated all XLF localization files
- Added error code to `ErrorFacts.cs`

âœ… **Parser Implementation:**
- Modified `parsePropertyPatternClause` local function in `ParsePatternContinued` to detect identifier followed by `{`
- When detected, the parser now:
  - Consumes the misplaced identifier token
  - Parses the property pattern
  - Reports the new CS8525 error with the variable name
  - Places the identifier token as skipped syntax on the property pattern
  - Continues parsing to provide better recovery

âœ… **Testing:**
- Added 1 test in `PatternParsingTests.cs`:
  - `DesignatorBeforePropertyPattern` - tests `string s { Length: 5 }`
- All 301 existing pattern parsing tests still pass
- Verified the exact scenario from issue #50220

### Scope
This fix only handles the property pattern case (`x { ... }`). Positional patterns (`x ( ... )`) are not covered by this change.

### Validation
- âœ… Builds successfully with no warnings
- âœ… All 302 pattern parsing tests pass (301 passed, 1 skipped)
- âœ… Correct syntax continues to work without the new error
- âœ… Error message is clear and concise
- âœ… Simplified implementation with direct token consumption
- âœ… No security vulnerabilities introduced

Fixes #50220

Issues.Title: Fix CS1003 error message when expression follows identifier without '='
Issues.Body:
## Plan: Fix CS1003 Error Message for Missing '=' in Variable Declarations

- [x] Understand the current parser behavior in `ParseVariableDeclarator` method
- [x] Identify where to add the check for literal tokens after identifier
- [x] Implement the fix to detect expression tokens and insert missing '=' error
- [x] Create focused test cases for the fix
- [x] Build and test the changes
- [x] Verify the fix produces the expected error message
- [x] Add WorkItem attribute to all test methods referencing issue #44292
- [x] Extend fix to handle all expression types (not just literals)
- [x] Convert tests to use raw string literals
- [x] Remove IsTrueIdentifier check and add OpenBraceToken handling per review feedback
- [x] Document comprehensive manual verification of all expression types and edge cases
- [x] Fix comma/semicolon/equals check to apply only for identifiers
- [x] Correct documentation and add proper manual test verification
- [x] Add actual tests for unary, binary, and object creation expressions

## Changes

**Parser Enhancement** (`LanguageParser.cs`):
- Extended the detection to handle any token that can start an expression using `IsPossibleExpression()`
- Added explicit check for `OpenBraceToken` to handle array/collection initializers like `var a { 1, 2, 3 }`
- Refined logic: comma/semicolon/equals check now properly distinguishes between identifiers and other tokens
  - For identifiers: checks if next token is comma/semicolon/equals (indicates separate declarator, not missing equals)
  - For other tokens (literals, operators, keywords): always treats as missing equals
- Added comprehensive comments explaining the logic
- When an expression is detected after an identifier, creates a missing `=` token and parses as initializer

**Tests** (`DeclarationParsingTests.cs`):
- Added coverage for numeric, string, boolean, and null literal cases
- Added full tests with syntax tree verification for unary, binary, and object creation expressions
- All tests use raw string literals for consistency
- Each test includes WorkItem attribute linking to issue #44292
- Additional expression types documented in comments

## Example

```csharp
class C {
  int value 5;        // numeric literal â†’ error CS1003: Syntax error, '=' expected
  string s "hello";   // string literal â†’ error CS1003: Syntax error, '=' expected
  bool b true;        // boolean literal â†’ error CS1003: Syntax error, '=' expected
  int x new C();      // new expression â†’ error CS1003: Syntax error, '=' expected
  int y -z;           // unary expression â†’ error CS1003: Syntax error, '=' expected
  int a b;            // identifier followed by ; â†’ no error (separate declarations)
  var c { 1, 2 };     // open brace â†’ error CS1003: Syntax error, '=' expected
}
```

**Before**: `error CS1003: Syntax error, ',' expected`  
**After**: `error CS1003: Syntax error, '=' expected` (for literals and expressions)

Note: Identifiers followed by comma/semicolon/equals do not trigger the error, as `int x y;` is more likely meant as separate declarations rather than `int x = y;`.

- Fixes dotnet/roslyn#44292

Issues.Title: Suppress CS0119 when CS0075 is reported for negative cast
Issues.Body:
## Plan to Improve Error Reporting for Negative Cast to Enum âœ…

- [x] Understand the problem: When writing `(ConsoleColor)-1`, the compiler reports both CS0119 ("ConsoleColor is a type, which is not valid") and CS0075 ("To cast a negative value, you must enclose the value in parentheses")
- [x] Locate the relevant code:
  - CS0075 (ERR_PossibleBadNegCast) is reported in `Binder_Operators.cs` line 912
  - CS0119 (ERR_BadSKunknown) is reported in `Binder.ValueChecks.cs` via `CheckNotNamespaceOrType`
- [x] Modify the code to suppress CS0119 when CS0075 will be reported
  - **REVISED APPROACH**: Instead of filtering errors after they're added, prevent ERR_BadSKunknown from being reported in the first place
  - Modified `CheckNotNamespaceOrType` to check for the `(T)-X` syntactic pattern before reporting ERR_BadSKunknown
  - Created shared helper method `IsParenthesizedExpressionInPossibleBadNegCastContext` used by both `CheckNotNamespaceOrType` and `BindSimpleBinaryOperator`
  - **IMPORTANT**: Nested parentheses check only applies to TypeExpression case, not to dynamic identifier case
  - This ensures both places check for the exact same pattern consistently while preserving original semantics
  - Reverted complex diagnostic bag filtering logic in `Binder_Operators.cs`
  - Added comment noting synchronization requirement with `BindSimpleBinaryOperator`
- [x] Update existing tests to reflect the improved error behavior
  - Updated `PossibleBadNegCast` test to expect only CS0075 errors
  - Added `PossibleBadNegCastNestedParentheses` test to demonstrate behavior with nested parentheses
  - Updated test formatting to use raw string literals and WorkItem attribute
- [x] Run broader compiler tests to ensure no regressions
  - All 7 PossibleBadNegCast tests pass
  - Cleaner implementation following code review feedback
- [x] Run code review and security checks

## Summary

Successfully improved error reporting for negative cast to enum with a cleaner approach that prevents the error from being added rather than filtering it out afterward. Both places that need to detect the pattern now share the same helper method to ensure consistency.

### Example

**Before:**
```
error CS0119: 'ConsoleColor' is a type, which is not valid in the given context
error CS0075: To cast a negative value, you must enclose the value in parentheses.
```

**After:**
```
error CS0075: To cast a negative value, you must enclose the value in parentheses.
```

Issues.Body:
## Fix for Confusing Error Message for Tuple Arguments âœ…

Successfully fixed the issue where static type constraint errors in tuples were reported at the wrong location.

### Changes Made
1. âœ… **`Binder_Symbols.cs`**: Changed `BindTupleType` to use `argumentSyntax.Type.Location` instead of `argumentSyntax.Location` for unnamed tuple elements, so the location points to just the type part rather than the entire tuple element.

2. âœ… **`ConstraintsHelper.cs`**: Updated the `CheckConstraints` method for `NamedTypeSymbol` to use tuple element locations when reporting constraint errors for tuple types.

3. âœ… **`SymbolErrorTests.cs`**: Added comprehensive test `CS0718ERR_GenericArgIsStaticClass_Tuple` covering multiple scenarios (updated to use raw string literal and correct WorkItem URL to issue 20172):
   - Tuple as return type with static type in first position
   - Tuple as return type with static type in second position
   - Tuple with multiple static types
   - Tuple in local variable declaration

### Before
```csharp
static class X
{
    static (X, long) Foo() // Error reported on "Foo"
    {
        return default;
    }
}
```
Error: `(3,22): error CS0718: 'X': static types cannot be used as type arguments`

### After
```csharp
static class X
{
    static (X, long) Foo() // Error reported on "X"
    {
        return default;
    }
}
```
Error: `(3,13): error CS0718: 'X': static types cannot be used as type arguments`

### Verification
- [x] All CS0718 tests pass (2/2)
- [x] New comprehensive test added and passing
- [x] Changes committed and pushed
- [x] Updated test to use raw string literal
- [x] Updated WorkItem URL to issue 20172

Issues.Title: Improve async iterator diagnostic by removing redundant error
Issues.Body:
## Improvement to async iterator diagnostics - Complete âœ…

This PR improves the diagnostic experience when an async iterator method (returning `IAsyncEnumerable<T>` or `IAsyncEnumerator<T>`) with `yield` statements is missing the `async` keyword.

**Before:**
Two redundant errors were reported:
```
error CS8403: Method 'C.M(int)' with an iterator block must be 'async' to return 'IAsyncEnumerator<int>'
error CS4032: The 'await' operator can only be used within an async method. 
Consider marking this method with the 'async' modifier and changing its return type to 'Task<IAsyncEnumerator<int>>'.
```
âŒ Multiple errors with incorrect return type suggestion

**After:**
Single, clear error message:
```
error CS8403: Method 'C.M(int)' with an iterator block must be 'async' to return 'IAsyncEnumerator<int>'
```
âœ… One focused error without incorrect return type suggestion

## Changes

- Modified `Binder_Await.cs` to skip reporting await errors for async iterators since `ERR_IteratorMustBeAsync` is already reported by `ExecutableCodeBinder.ValidateIteratorMethod`
- Uses shared `InMethodBinder.IsAsyncStreamInterface` method to ensure consistent detection logic
- This eliminates redundant error messages and improves the diagnostic experience
- Added explanatory comment referencing where the primary error is reported
- Updated tests to expect only one error (ERR_IteratorMustBeAsync) instead of two
- Added test coverage for both `IAsyncEnumerable<T>` and `IAsyncEnumerator<T>` cases

## Test Results
- All 14 async iterator "returning" tests pass âœ…
- All 285 async iterator tests pass âœ…

Fixes #31113

Issues.Title: Fix redundant error reporting in deconstruction assignments
Issues.Body:
Fix redundant deconstruction errors

## Completed Work
- [x] Implemented `suppressErrors` parameter in `FailRemainingInferences` to suppress CS8130 errors when deconstruction fails
- [x] Updated test expectations to remove CS8130 errors in cases where deconstruction failed
- [x] Attempted to suppress CS8129 when CS1061 is reported (partially working)
- [x] Fixed whitespace formatting errors (removed trailing spaces from blank lines)
- [x] Added explicit test for original bug scenario with `object` type

## Changes Made

Added `DeconstructMethodMissing_WithImplicitlyTypedVariables` test that exactly matches the scenario from the original bug report to validate the fix. The test demonstrates that CS8130 errors are now properly suppressed when deconstruction fails.

## Current Status
The fix successfully suppresses CS8130 errors (type inference failures) when deconstruction fails, which addresses part of the issue. However, suppressing CS8129 when CS1061 is reported is proving more complex than expected due to the way the diagnostic system works.

## Known Issues
CS8129 is still being reported alongside CS1061 in some cases. The `memberAccess.HasErrors` check doesn't seem to reflect the diagnostics that were added to the diagnostic bag. This requires further investigation into how the Roslyn diagnostic system works.

## Next Steps
The CS8130 suppression is working correctly and provides value. The CS8129 suppression needs more investigation to understand why `memberAccess.HasErrors` doesn't reflect CS1061 being reported.

Issues.Title: Fix tuple type inference for deconstruction with partially-typed elements
Issues.Body:
Type inference for tuple deconstruction fails completely when any element lacks a natural type, even for elements that could be inferred. For example, `var (x, y) = (1, null);` fails to infer both `x` and `y`, when `x` should infer as `int`.

## Changes

**Binder_Expressions.cs**
- Modified `BindToNaturalType` to construct tuple types from partially-typed tuple literals
- Null literals without types are converted to `object` for error recovery
- Recursively binds each tuple element to natural type, then creates tuple type from converted elements

**CodeGenDeconstructTests.cs**
- Updated `FailedInferenceInDeconstructionInScript` to expect successful inference for elements with natural types

## Example

```csharp
// Before: both x and y fail to infer (tuple has no type)
var (x, y) = (1, null);  // Error on x, error on y

// After: x infers successfully, y gets object type
var (x, y) = (1, null);  // x is int, y is object
```

The fix enables type inference to proceed element-by-element rather than failing wholesale when the tuple construction encounters untyped elements.

Issues.Title: Suppress ERR_BadRetType and ERR_MethDelegateMismatch for delegate conversions with omitted type arguments
Issues.Body:
## Fix for Delegate Conversion Error Messages with Omitted Type Arguments

### Problem
When using delegate conversion for extension methods with omitted type arguments (e.g., `Method<>`), the compiler reports confusing error messages:
```
error CS0407: '? FooExtensions.ExtensionMethod1<?>(object)' has the wrong return type
```
or
```
error CS0123: No overload for 'ExtensionMethod1' matches delegate 'Action<object>'
```

The `?` symbols appear because the return type or parameter types can't be determined when type arguments are omitted.

### Solution
Suppress ERR_BadRetType when the method's return type contains error types, and prevent ERR_MethDelegateMismatch from being reported as a fallback when method signatures contain error types in return types or parameters (from omitted type arguments). Since a more specific error (ERR_OmittedTypeArgument) is already reported, the confusing errors with `?` symbols are redundant.

### Changes Made
1. **OverloadResolutionResult.cs**: Modified `HadReturnMismatch` to suppress ERR_BadRetType when return type contains error types
2. **Conversions.cs**: Added check in `ReportDelegateOrFunctionPointerMethodGroupDiagnostics` to mark as having errors when candidate methods have error types in return type or parameters, preventing ERR_MethDelegateMismatch from being reported as a fallback
3. **BindingTests.cs**: 
   - Updated test expectations for return type case to remove the now-suppressed ERR_BadRetType diagnostic
   - Added new test `MissingTypeArgumentInGenericExtensionMethod_ParameterType` to verify parameter types are also handled correctly

### Result
**Before (return type):**
```
error CS8389: Omitting the type argument is not allowed in the current context
error CS0407: '? FooExtensions.ExtensionMethod1<?>(object)' has the wrong return type
```

**After (return type):**
```
error CS8389: Omitting the type argument is not allowed in the current context
```

**Before (parameter type):**
```
error CS8389: Omitting the type argument is not allowed in the current context
error CS0123: No overload for 'ExtensionMethod1' matches delegate 'Action<object>'
```

**After (parameter type):**
```
error CS8389: Omitting the type argument is not allowed in the current context
```

Fixes dotnet/roslyn#16041

> <issue_title>Delegate conversion for extension methods contain wrong type error messages when omitting type arguments</issue_title>
> <issue_description>**Repro:**
> 
> ```csharp
> public static class FooExtensions
> {
>     public static T ExtensionMethod1<T>(this object obj) => default(T);
> }
> public class Class1
> {
>     public void Test()
>     {
>         System.Func<object> delegateConversion1 = "literal".ExtensionMethod1<>;
>     }
> }
> ```
> 
> **Error Displayed:**
> `Error CS0407: '? FooExtensions.ExtensionMethod1<?>(object)' has the wrong return type`
> 
> **Expected:**
> Display a more meaningful error instead of using `?`
> 
> Discovered by dotnet/roslyn#15966
> </issue_description>
> 
> <agent_instructions>@copilot see if this is something easy to fix.  Specifically, we should see that the return type of the function is an error type, or some sort of non-good-type, (hence why it is displayed as `?`).    And, as such, we don't need to report this issue since we will have already reported some other problem.</agent_instructions>

Issues.Title: Prefer expanded form for error reporting when params arguments are convertible
Issues.Body:
## Plan: Fix Overload Resolution Error Reporting for Params Collections

- [x] Understand the issue and comments
- [x] Identify that the fix should be at form selection level, not error reporting level
- [x] Modify PreferExpandedFormOverNormalForm to prefer expanded form when normal form has bad params argument
- [x] Simplify redundant condition checks (addresses @CyrusNajmabadi's feedback)
- [x] Update test WorkItem URLs to reference correct issue #12933
- [x] Clean up test code comments
- [x] Add tests for issue #43920
- [x] Remove comments from within test string literals
- [x] Build and test - all tests passing!

## Summary of Changes

**File: OverloadResolution.cs**

Simplified `PreferExpandedFormOverNormalForm` to remove redundant condition checks. The logic now simply checks if `haveBadArgumentForLastParameter(normalResult)` is true and prefers the expanded form in that case, which covers both scenarios:
1. Both normal and expanded forms have bad arguments for the last parameter
2. Normal form has a bad argument but expanded form doesn't

This makes the logic clearer while maintaining the same behavior: prefer expanded form when normal form has a bad argument for the params parameter, which ensures more accurate error messages.

**File: OverloadResolutionTests.cs**

- Added test cases for the params error suppression functionality
- Updated WorkItem URLs to reference the correct issue #12933
- Cleaned up test method comments (both outside and inside string literals)
- Added two test cases for issue #43920:
  - `ParamsErrorSuppression_Issue43920`: Tests with `params object[]` signature
  - `ParamsErrorSuppression_Issue43920_StringParams`: Tests with `params string[]` signature (the specific signature from the issue)

**Test Results:**
- âœ… All 426 overload resolution tests passing
- âœ… All 4 params error suppression tests passing (including both #43920 tests)
- âœ… No regressions

**Issues Fixed:**
- Fixes #12933 - Main issue about confusing params error messages
- Fixes #43920 - Related issue also addressed by the same fix

Issues.Title: Prefer delegate-accepting overload in error messages when lambda argument is present
Issues.Body:
## Plan: Improve error message for overloaded generic delegate-accepting methods âœ…

When overload resolution fails and there's a lambda/anonymous method argument, the compiler now prefers reporting errors about overloads that accept delegates in that position, and also prefers reporting errors about non-lambda arguments when both lambda and non-lambda errors exist.

### Implementation Plan:
- [x] Understand the current behavior
- [x] Modify error reporting to prefer delegate-accepting overloads  
- [x] Create focused tests for the scenario
- [x] Build and test changes - all OverloadResolutionTests pass (231 tests)
- [x] Run broader test suite - LambdaTests (319 tests) pass
- [x] Added edge case tests
- [x] Extended fix to also handle issue #10672
- [x] Updated test expectations in DelegateTypeTests and SemanticErrorTests
- [x] All tests passing (819 DelegateTypeTests + 784 SemanticErrorTests)

### Changes Made:

**`OverloadResolutionResult.cs`:**
1. Modified `HadBadArguments` to detect when a lambda is converting to a non-delegate type
2. Check for type inference failures on delegate-accepting overloads and report those instead
3. Updated `GetFirstMemberKind` to prefer delegate-accepting candidates when lambda arguments are present
4. Modified `HadLambdaConversionError` to check if there are bad arguments in non-lambda positions
5. If lambda errors exist but there are also bad non-lambda arguments and a delegate-accepting overload, report the non-lambda argument errors instead
6. Added `HasDelegateParameterForLambdaArgument` helper method
7. Added `HasLambdaArgumentConvertingToNonDelegate` helper method
8. Added `HasBadArgumentsInNonLambdaPositions` helper method

**Test Updates:**
- Updated `DelegateTypeTests.OverloadResolution_33`, `OverloadResolution_35`, `OverloadResolution_36`, `OverloadResolution_38`
- Updated `SemanticErrorTests.CS1061ERR_NoSuchMemberOrExtension05`
- These updates reflect the improved error messages that now correctly point to delegate-accepting overloads

### Issues Fixed:

**Issue #21950:**
```csharp
M(x => { });
static void M(string s) { }
static void M<T>(Action<T> a) { }

// âŒ Before: CS1660: Cannot convert lambda expression to type 'string'
// âœ… After: CS0411: The type arguments for method 'Program.M<T>(Action<T>)' cannot be inferred
```

**Issue #10672:**
```csharp
Task.Run(() => { }, TaskCreationOptions.LongRunning);

// âŒ Before: CS1643: Not all code paths return a value in lambda expression of type 'Func<Task>'
// âœ… After: CS1503: Argument 2: cannot convert from 'TaskCreationOptions' to 'CancellationToken'
```

**Additional improvements** (reflected in updated tests):
- When multiple generic overloads exist, now reports errors about ones that accept delegates
- For LINQ methods like `Select`, now prefers `Enumerable.Select` (takes `Func`) over `Queryable.Select` (takes `Expression<Func>`)

All test failures were appropriate - they reflected the improved error reporting behavior.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->



<details>

<summary>Original prompt</summary>

> 
> ----
> 
> *This section details on the original issue you should resolve*
> 
> <issue_title>Confusing error message for overloaded generic delegate-accepting method</issue_title>
> <issue_description>I have the following code:
> 
> ``` c#
> using System;
> 
> class Program
> {
>     static void Main()
>     {
>         M(x => { });
>     }
> 
>     static void M(string s)
>     {
>     }
> 
>     static void M<T>(Action<T> a)
>     {
>     }
> }
> ```
> 
> It produces the following error:
> 
> > CS1660    Cannot convert lambda expression to type 'string' because it is not a delegate type
> 
> I think that a human can clearly see that the code is attempting to call the delegate-accepting overload, but is missing a type argument (`M<int>(x => { });`) or explicit parameter type (`M((int x) => { });`).
> 
> But the compiler shows error message that's related to the first (`string`-accepting) overload, which I think is confusing.
> </issue_description>
> 
> <agent_instructions>@copilot see if this is easy to make better.  specifically, in an overload resolution error case, when determining the best overload to report, if there is a lambda/anonymous-method, prefer one of the overloads that takes a delegate in that position/named-arg-location.</agent_instructions>
>

> </comments>

Issues.Title: Fix cascaded diagnostics when goto statement label not found
Issues.Body:
## Fix Cascaded Diagnostics When Label Not Found âœ…

Successfully fixed the issue where the C# compiler reported cascaded errors when goto statements (including `goto case` and `goto default`) failed to bind due to missing labels.

### Problem
When a goto statement fails to bind because the target label doesn't exist, the compiler creates a `BoundBadStatement`. During flow analysis, only `BoundGotoStatement` calls `SetUnreachable()`, but `BoundBadStatement` does not, leading to cascaded false-positive errors about:
- Control cannot fall through from one case label to another (ERR_SwitchFallThrough)
- Control cannot fall out of switch from final case label (ERR_SwitchFallOut)  
- Not all code paths return a value (ERR_ReturnExpected)

### Solution
Modified `AbstractFlowPass.VisitBadStatement` to check if the bad statement originated from a goto statement syntax (including goto, goto case, and goto default), and if so, set the state to unreachable to prevent cascaded diagnostics.

### Changes Made
- [x] Modified `AbstractFlowPass.VisitBadStatement` in flow analysis
- [x] Added comprehensive tests for all three goto scenarios (goto label, goto case, goto default)
- [x] Updated one existing test that was expecting the cascaded error
- [x] Applied code review feedback (pattern matching syntax, correct issue reference, test cleanup)
- [x] All tests pass: 95/95 flow diagnostic tests, 75/75 switch tests
- [x] Security check complete (no vulnerabilities found)

Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/issues/5243

Issues.Title: Add replacement property names to VB syntax obsolete attributes
Issues.Body:
Obsolete attributes on VB syntax properties showed generic "This member is obsolete." messages without indicating replacement properties, forcing developers to search metadata or documentation.

## Changes

Updated 54 obsolete attribute messages across 4 VB syntax files:

- **MethodBlockBaseSyntax.vb**: `Begin` â†’ `SubNewStatement`, `End` â†’ `EndSubStatement`, etc. for ConstructorBlock, MethodBlock, and OperatorBlock
- **MethodBaseSyntax.vb**: `Keyword` â†’ `{Type}Keyword` (e.g., `SubOrFunctionKeyword`, `EventKeyword`) for 9 statement types
- **TypeBlockSyntax.vb**: `Begin` â†’ `{Type}Statement`, `End` â†’ `End{Type}Statement` for Class, Structure, Interface, Module blocks
- **TypeStatementSyntax.vb**: `Keyword` â†’ `{Type}Keyword` for Class, Structure, Interface, Module statements

## Example

```vb
' Before
<Obsolete("This member is obsolete.", True)>
Public Shadows ReadOnly Property Begin As SubNewStatementSyntax

' After
<Obsolete("This member is obsolete. Use SubNewStatement instead.", True)>
Public Shadows ReadOnly Property Begin As SubNewStatementSyntax
```

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->



<details>

<summary>Original prompt</summary>

> 
> ----
> 
> *This section details on the original issue you should resolve*
> 
> <issue_title>Obsolete messages could be more helpful</issue_title>
> <issue_description>The upgrade from beta1 to rc1 NuGet packages introduced a number of `Obsolete` members.  The messages though are not very helpful:
> 
> ```
> [Obsolete("This member is obsolete.", true)]
> public ClassStatementSyntax Begin { get; }
> ```
> 
> This just tells the user the member is obsolete but gives them no direction on how to fix the problem.  Intellisense is also not helpful here because `Begin` has no matches.  I'm forced to go to the metadata view of the file and search for the new member.  
> 
>  A much better message would be:
> 
> ```
> [Obsolete("This member is obsolete, use ClassStatement instead", true)]
> public ClassStatementSyntax Begin { get; }
> ```
> </issue_description>
> 
> <agent_instructions>@copilot look for all these obsolete cases on VB syntax.  For example:
> 
> ```c#
> ConstructorBlockSyntax ...
>         <Obsolete("This member is obsolete.", True)>
>         Public Shadows ReadOnly Property Begin As SubNewStatementSyntax
> ```
> 
> Update the comments to explain which statement to use instead.  For example, for ConstructorBlockSyntax you can see that it should be `<Obsolete("This member is obsolete. Use BlockStatement instead.", True)>`
> 
> You only need to update the obsolete messages on VB syntax nodes that do not say which new property to use. </agent_instructions>
> 
> ## Comments on the Issue (you are @copilot in this section)
> 
> <comments>
> <comment_new><author>@jaredpar</author><body>
> Also as an aside: 
> 
> I generally find the move from `Begin` and `End` to type specific names results in a loss of productivity.  Before when working with rewrites on any block construct I could reliably grab `Begin` and `End` to rewrite the tree.  Now I have to remember the type specific name for begin and end on every single block construct.  That results in a lot of searching when instead I should be coding. 
> 
> Even if we want to keep type specific notation it would help if the begin construct began with `Begin` just as the end construct begins with `End`.  This would make it enormously easier to find in intellisense.  
> </body></comment_new>
> </comments>
> 


</details>

- Fixes dotnet/roslyn#630

Issues.Title: Fix solution filter path separators for .slnx files on Windows
Issues.Body:
MSBuild validates solution filter (`.slnf`) project paths against the referenced solution file using normalized Windows paths (backslashes), even when the solution file (`.slnx`) uses forward slashes in its XML.

## Changes

- Updated `TestProjectsWithShared.slnf` to use backslashes in project paths when referencing `.slnx` files
  - `TestProject/TestProject.csproj` â†’ `TestProject\\TestProject.csproj`
  - `SharedProject/SharedProject.shproj` â†’ `SharedProject\\SharedProject.shproj`

This aligns with existing `.slnf` files in the repository that reference `.slnx` solutions (e.g., `TestAppWithSlnxAndSolutionFilters/App.slnf`).

Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/51398  
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/51481

Issues.Title: File-Based App Conversion Incorrectly Includes JSON Files from Other Apps
Issues.Body:
### Describe the bug When using `dotnet project convert` command on a console app file, the CLI is incorrectly including JSON files from other file-based apps in the same directory. i am using `DotNet 10` and `VS Code` ## Workspace Structure Before Conversion ``` File Based Apps/ â”œâ”€â”€ MyConsoleApp.cs (Console app) â”œâ”€â”€ MyWebApp.cs (Web app) â”œâ”€â”€ MyWebApp.run.json (Config for MyWebApp) â”œâ”€â”€ MyWebApp.settings.json (Config for MyWebApp) ``` ## Command Executed ``` dotnet project convert .\MyConsoleApp.cs ``` ## Expected Behavior The conversion should only create a project folder for `MyConsoleApp.cs` without including any JSON configuration files, or should only include JSON files that are specifically named for MyConsoleApp (e.g., `MyConsoleApp.run.json`, `MyConsoleApp.settings.json`). ## Actual Behavior The CLI created the following structure: ``` MyConsoleApp/ â”œâ”€â”€ MyConsoleApp.cs â”œâ”€â”€ MyConsoleApp.csproj â”œâ”€â”€ MyWebApp.run.json âŒ Should NOT be included â””â”€â”€ MyWebApp.settings.json âŒ Should NOT be included ``` The `MyWebApp.run.json` and `MyWebApp.settings.json` files were incorrectly copied into the `MyConsoleApp` folder, even though they are configuration files for the separate `MyWebApp.cs` web application. ### To Reproduce ### Exceptions (if any) ### Further technical details
details of dotnet --info

.NET SDK: Version: 10.0.100 Commit: b0f34d51fc Workload version: 10.0.100-manifests.355811b7 MSBuild version: 18.0.2+b0f34d51f Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.26200 OS Platform: Windows RID: win-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\10.0.100\
- The IDE (VS / VS Code/ VS4Mac) you're running on, and its version - VS Code ``` Version: 1.106.0 (user setup) Commit: ac4cbdf48759c7d8c3eb91ffe6bb04316e263c57 Date: 2025-11-11T16:02:25.943Z Electron: 37.7.0 ElectronBuildId: 12597478 Chromium: 138.0.7204.251 Node.js: 22.20.0 V8: 13.8.258.32-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26200 ```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "File-Based App Conversion Incorrectly Includes JSON Files from Other Apps" (#51769)
